title: How to Name a Song You've Written

steps.title: Write a 2-3 word summary of your song.
steps.content: Write a 2-3 word summary of your song. Write about the emotions in the song, the story that it tells, or how you felt when you were writing. Breaking it down into short phrases will help you to understand what your listener will think the song is about. [1] X Research source It’s okay to have a summary that is longer than 2-3 words. Many popular artists have longer titles for their songs. Songs like “Thinking Out Loud” and “Lights Down Low” are great examples of short phrases that summarize the emotion or story of a song.

steps.title: Take a line from the chorus, bridge, or hook.
steps.content: Take a line from the chorus, bridge, or hook. It might be the case that your title is already hidden somewhere within the lyrics you’ve written. Search for a line or part of a line that really sums up the emotion behind the song, or a line that is repeated often throughout the song. [2] X Research source Songwriters sometimes use repeated lines as the title because they can help the listener avoid the age-old problem of knowing the lyrics but not remembering the title of the song. For example, “Shape of You” is taken directly from the lyrics of the song in the chorus.

steps.title: Name the song after your emotions.
steps.content: Name the song after your emotions. If your song expresses one specific emotion that lasts through the whole song, you can use this in the name. We do not listen only to singers with good voices but also who have feelings, hearts, and souls. You need to feel your song so your audiences feel it, and if you name it after your emotions, it will reach its right audience at the right time. You can be as simple or broad as you would like with your wording or be very specific with an exact emotion. A great example of this is “Happy,” which encompasses the entire attitude of the song! "Sorry" is another good example of this method.

steps.title: Come up with a unique way to say a cliche phrase.
steps.content: Come up with a unique way to say a cliche phrase. Your song might be expressing an emotion like “I love you” or “I miss you” but these titles are often overused. To avoid this problem, you might brainstorm how you can express those feelings other than saying that phrase. [3] X Research source "Love on the Brain" references love and the emotion without specifically saying “I love you” in the title.

steps.title: Choose a color that represents the song.
steps.content: Choose a color that represents the song. Colors and emotion are closely related, and most people associate specific emotions with a color. Close your eyes and think about what you’ve written and what color comes to mind. Use that color and a noun or verb to name the song. [4] X Research source Some great examples of this are “Purple Rain,” or “The Lady in Red.”

steps.title: Name the song after the time or place it was written.
steps.content: Name the song after the time or place it was written. Your environment can be a huge source of inspiration. If you wrote the song on a Saturday afternoon, or became inspired on a trip to Paris, you can use the environmental as part of your title. [5] X Research source "New York New York" is a famous song that uses this method.

steps.title: Modify an idiomatic expression or pun.
steps.content: Modify an idiomatic expression or pun. A lot of songwriters use wordplay in their titles to make them unique. In this case, the title doesn’t necessarily have to be about summarizing the song, but more about making a joke or clever remark based on one part of the song. [6] X Research source For example, “Leave the Night On” is a play on the phrase “leave the light on.”

steps.title: Pull lines from books, movies, or even history.
steps.content: Pull lines from books, movies, or even history. If you have a favorite movie or novel that inspired you when you were writing, you can use a short phrase from the story to name your song. A lot of songwriters also use names of historical figures or events as titles, regardless of what the song is about. [7] X Research source For example “Paul Revere” by the Beastie Boys doesn’t really have anything to do with the historical figure other than its name. On the other hand, the song “Pompeii” by Bastille is about the volcanic explosion at Pompeii.

steps.title: Try using an online song title generator.
steps.content: Try using an online song title generator. There are plenty of websites online that can come up with a title based on a word or a few words that you input. Even if it doesn’t give you a name, it can still give you some ideas based on its suggestions. If you can't find any, try googling "song title generator."
